The approach of this paper is based on the methods of queueing
theory. Without loss of generality we assume that in each of its
states, the random walk spends exponentially distributed time with
mean 1 prior moving to another (neighbor) state. Then, under this
assumption we study the functional $\varphi_t=\|\mathbf{S}_t\|$. The
functional $\varphi_t$ is a birth-and-death process with
specifically defined birth and death parameters. The values of these
parameters are found in \cite{Ab}. The contribution of this paper is
to study the number of customers served during a busy period of the
state-dependent queueing system, the parameters of which (arrival
and service rates) are the specifically modified parameters of the
birth-and-death process $\varphi_t$. If the number of served
customers during the busy period is finite with probability 1, then
the eventual return probability of the random walk is equal to 1.
Otherwise, if the distribution of the number of served customers is
not proper, then the eventual return probability of the random walk
must be the same as the probability that the number of served
customers during the busy period is finite.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section \ref{S2},
the basic result of the paper is presented. In Section \ref{S3}, we
recall the connection between the random walk in ${Z}^d$ and
birth-and-death process. We also establish important properties of
the number of served customers during the busy period. Specifically,
we demonstrate that specifically defined transformation of the
birth-and-death parameters (measure transform) do not change the
probability distribution function of the number of customers served
during a busy period. In Section \ref{S4}, we derive the asymptotic
recurrence relations for the required generating functions and prove
basic theorem of the paper. In Section \ref{S5}, we provide
numerical calculations. In Section \ref{S6} we formulate and discuss
an open problem. In Appendix 1 we recall necessary results of
\cite{Ab} in order to make the paper self-contained. Appendix 2
contains the listing of the C/C++ program used for the numerical
calculations of the paper.

prevtext:
\title[Eventual return probability in multidimensional random walks]
{Eventual return probability in multidimensional random walks}
\author{Vyacheslav M. Abramov}
\address{24 Sagan Drive, Cranbourne North, Victoria-3977, Australia}
\email{vabramov126@gmail.com}


\subjclass{60G50; 60J80; 60C05; 60K25}
\keywords{Multi-dimensional random walk; birth-and-death process;
Markovian single-server queues; Poisson process; eventual return probability;
busy period; change of measure}





\begin{abstract}
It is well-known that the simple symmetric random walk of dimension
1 or 2 is recurrent, i.e. being started from the origin, it returns
to the original point infinitely many times. Simple symmetric random
walks of dimension higher than 2 are not recurrent. The present
paper derives simple limiting recurrence relations, which enable us
to find an approximate value of the eventual return probability for
a simple symmetric random walk of an arbitrary dimension $d$. The
numerical calculations show that the eventual return probabilities
for the simple symmetric random walks in ${Z}^3$ and ${Z}^4$ are
close to 1.
\end{abstract}
\maketitle

\section{Introduction}

It is well-known that the simple symmetric random walk of dimension
1 or 2 is recurrent, i.e. being started from the origin, it returns
to the original point infinitely many times. Simple symmetric random
walks of dimension higher than 2 are not recurrent. That is, their
eventual return probability is less than 1.

The proofs of these facts are well-known, and nowadays they can be
found in many textbooks on probability (e.g. see \cite{Gr},
\cite{Sp} etc). The known result on the eventual return probability
is very formal. It is based on the well-known standard technique of
the theory of Markov chains, hardly useful and actually enables us
to only check whether or not the random walk is recurrent. In
\cite{Gr}, page 478, the authors claim without any justification
that the eventual return probability for the simple symmetric random
walk in $Z^3$ is approximately $.65$. We reckon that this conclusion
could be made on the basis of rough numerical estimate. According to
our analysis and numerical calculations, the eventual return
probabilities for random walks in ${Z}^3$ and ${Z}^4$ both are close
to 1 (see Section \ref{S5} for the results of numerical analysis).

In fact, the problem of calculation of the eventual return
probability is a difficult \textit{open} problem, which could not be
solved for the long time (the original version of Spitzer's book
\cite{Sp} was published in 1964) in the framework of well-known
traditional methods of the theory of random walks.

In recent paper \cite{Ab}, the author suggests a new combinatorial
approach to multidimensional random walks, where the most important
issue is the connection between multidimensional random walks and
birth-and-death processes with specifically defined birth and death
parameters. In the present paper, developing the results of
\cite{Ab} we derive the recurrence relations for the eventual return
probability of the simple symmetric random walk in ${Z}^d$.

The definition of the simple symmetric random walk in ${Z}^d$ is as
follows. The random walk $\mathbf{S}_t$ $=\Big(S_t^{(1)}$,
$S_t^{(2)}$,\ldots, $S_t^{(d)}\Big)$, $t=0,1,\ldots$, is
characterized by the following equations:
\begin{eqnarray}
\mathbf{S}_0&=&\mathbf{0},\label{eq-1.1}\\
\mathbf{S}_{t}&=&\mathbf{S}_{t-1}+\mathbf{e}_t, \
t\geq1\label{eq-1.2}
\end{eqnarray}
where $\mathbf{0}$ is the $d$-dimensional vector of zeros, and the
random vector $\mathbf{e}_t$ is defined as follows. Let
$\mathbf{1}_i$ denote the vector the $i$th coordinate of which is 1
and the rest coordinates are zeros. Then, the vector $\mathbf{e}_t$
is one of the $2d$ vectors $\{\pm \mathbf{1}_i, i=1,2,\ldots,d\}$
randomly chosen with the equal probability $1/(2d)$.

For any vector $\mathbf{n}$ $=\Big(n^{(1)}$, $n^{(2)}$,\ldots,
$n^{(d)}\Big)$ $\in{Z}^d$, its norm is denoted by
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\|\mathbf{n}\|=\sum_{i=1}^{d}|n^{(i)}|." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>∥</mo><mi>𝐧</mi><mo>∥</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>d</mi></munderover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msup><mi>n</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

The details of the proof are given in \cite{Ab} and now is provided
in Appendix 1. Following the assumption that, in each of its state
the random walk spends exponentially distributed time with mean 1,
we arrive at the conclusion that $\varphi_t$ is the birth-and-death
process with the parameters

Hence, the eventual return probability for the random walk must
coincide with the probability that the busy period of the
state-dependent queueing system, with rate arrivals $\lambda_j$ and
service rates $\mu_j$, is finite. In further consideration, it is
more convenient to deal with the \textit{number of customers} served
during a busy period rather than with a busy period itself. The
probability that the number of customers served during a busy period
is finite is the same as the probability that a busy period is
finite.

The reason that we are going to work with the number of customers
served during a busy period rather than with a busy period itself is
that the derivation of the Laplace-Stieltjes transform for a busy
period of such the queueing system, in which both the interarrival
and service times are state-dependent, is a hard problem. The
derivation of the generating function for the number of served
customers during a busy period is much easier. By using the measure
transform the original problem can be reduced to a more particular
one, in which the arrival process is homogeneous. Then the problem
can be solved by known methods.

the number of times during a busy period of the state-dependent
queueing system (defined by the set of parameters $\mathcal{X}$)
when an arriving customer meets $n$ customers in the system.
Apparently, $\nu(\mathcal{X})=\sum_{n=0}^\infty f(n,\mathcal{X})$.
(If the busy period is not finite, then the both sides of the
equality are infinite.)

\section{Proof of Theorem \ref{t1}}\label{S4}
The proof of Theorem \ref{t1} consists of three parts. In the first
part we derive the infinite system of equations for $P_m(z)$,
$m=0,1,\ldots$. In the second part we represent the system of the
obtained equations in the form of limiting relation for integer
parameter (index) $n$ increasing to infinity. In the final part we
complete the proof of the theorem. As before, we use the notation: $
p(n)=({C(n+1)+C_0(n+1)})/({2C(n+1)}) $, $q(n)=1-p(n)$,
$j=0,1,\ldots.$


\subsection{Infinite system of equations}

The result of this section is the following lemma.
\begin{lem}\label{l2}
The generating function $P_0(z)$ satisfies the following system:

\end{lem}

\begin{proof}

Notice, that $\mathsf{P}\{\nu(\nabla^m\mathcal{Y})=k\}$ is the
distribution of the number of customers served during the $m+1$st
busy cycle, the time interval that starts when there are $m+1$
customers in the system until the moment when there remain $m$
customers, and $P_m(z)$ is the corresponding generating function.
Using the arguments similar to those in \cite{Tak}, we obtain as
follows. If during the service time of a first (tagged) customer no
arrivals occur, then the number of customers served during the
$m+1$st busy cycle is 1, and, hence, the corresponding conditional
generating function is $ z. $ If during the service time of a tagged
customer there are $n$ arrivals, then the conditional generating
function of the $m+1$st busy cycle is $z\prod_{j=m}^{m+n-1}P_j(z).$
Applying now the total probability formula, we arrive at
\eqref{eq-3.6}.
\end{proof}

relations for the generation functions $P_0(z)$. Note first that

the desired inequality. The following use of induction enables us to
easily prove the inequality
$P_{n-i}^{(2)}(z,n+1)>P_{n-i}^{(1)}(z,n)$, $i=1,2,\ldots,n$, by
comparing the terms $P_{n-i+1}^{(2)}(z,n+1)$ with the corresponding
smaller terms $P_{n-i+1}^{(1)}(z,n)$.

Thus, $P_0(z,n)$ is monotone increasing, and hence the limit as
$n\to\infty$ of $P_0(z,n)$ is defined and coincides with $P_0(z)$.

\subsection{Final part of the proof}
In order to find the eventual return probability, we are to use the
Tauberian theorem by letting $z$ to tend to 1, that is, to find the
limit $\lim_{z\uparrow1}P_0(z)$.

For the system of recurrence relations given by \eqref{eq-4.7} and
\eqref{eq-4.2}, the limits in $n$ and in $z$ are interchangeable,
since double sequences are bounded and monotone increasing in $n$
and $z$. Then we arrive at the following system:

which is similar to \eqref{eq-4.5}, and then define recurrently
$P_{n-i}^{(2)}(z,n+1)$ adding upper index (2). Since $p(n)$
increases and $q(n)$ decreases, then
$P_{n+1}(z,n+1)>P_{n}^{(1)}(z,n)$. Furthermore,
$P_{n}^{(2)}(z,n+1)>P_{n}^{(1)}(z,n)$. Indeed, replacing in the
representation for $P_{n}^{(2)}(z,n+1)$ the term $P_{n+1}(z,n+1)$ by
the smaller term $P_{n}^{(1)}(z,n)$, we can easily see the truth of
the desired inequality. The following use of induction enables us to
easily prove the inequality
$P_{n-i}^{(2)}(z,n+1)>P_{n-i}^{(1)}(z,n)$, $i=1,2,\ldots,n$, by
comparing the terms $P_{n-i+1}^{(2)}(z,n+1)$ with the corresponding
smaller terms $P_{n-i+1}^{(1)}(z,n)$.

Thus, $P_0(z,n)$ is monotone increasing, and hence the limit as
$n\to\infty$ of $P_0(z,n)$ is defined and coincides with $P_0(z)$.

\subsection{Final part of the proof}
In order to find the eventual return probability, we are to use the
Tauberian theorem by letting $z$ to tend to 1, that is, to find the
limit $\lim_{z\uparrow1}P_0(z)$.

For the system of recurrence relations given by \eqref{eq-4.7} and
\eqref{eq-4.2}, the limits in $n$ and in $z$ are interchangeable,
since double sequences are bounded and monotone increasing in $n$
and $z$. Then we arrive at the following system:

mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex23.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="C(n)=dN=d\sum_{i=1}^{d}2^{i}\binom{d}{i}\binom{n-1}{i-1}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>d</mi></munderover><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>i</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\binom</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\binom</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
If $\varphi_{t-1}=n$, then the phase space for $\varphi_t$ contains
$2C(n)$ states, since each of $C(n)$ coordinates can increase or
decrease by unit. Then, the possible number of events
$\{\varphi_t=n+1\}$ is $C(n)+C_0(n)$, while the possible number of
events $\{\varphi_t=n-1\}$ is $C(n)-C_0(n)$ and all possibilities
are equally likely. The fact that the process $\varphi_t$ spends in
each state an exponentially distributed time with mean 1 enables us
to conclude that $\varphi_t$ is the birth-and-death process with the
birth parameter $\lambda_n=C(n)+C_0(n)$ and death parameter
$\mu_n=C(n)-C_0(n)$.

\subsection*{A.2. Proof of Lemma \ref{l3}}

there are remain only $j$ customers in the system. Since the busy
period starts with a single customer, then $a_1^{(0)}$ coincides
with the busy period start, $d_1^{(0)}$ coincides with the busy
period completion, and $z_0=1$.  For $1\leq j$, the time intervals

nexttext:
Let us delete the intervals of (A.3) from those of (A.4) and merge
the ends. Then, according to the property of the lack of memory, the
number of merged points in each of the intervals of (A.4) coincides
in distribution with the number of arrivals per service time
(provided that arrival and service rates are unchanged and
respectively equal to the values of parameters $\lambda_{j}$ and
$\mu_{j}$) and has geometric distribution with parameter
$\lambda_{j}/(\lambda_{j}+\mu_{j})$. This enables us to conclude
that $\{f(j,\mathcal{X})\}$ have the structure of branching process,
in which the distribution of the number of offspring in the $j$th
generation depends on the order number of generation, $j$, and is
described by \eqref{eq-3.3} and \eqref{eq-3.7}. Hence,
$f(j,\mathcal{X})=R_j$, and \eqref{eq-3.8} follows.
